webTitle: Business leaders should stop whingeing about Australia’s competitiveness

fields.standfirst: Instead of putting the onus on the government, business should look at how it can improve capital productivity
fields.body:
This week came yet again the calls from business that “we’ll all be rooned”. They started with the release of a report by the Business Council of Australia, and were accompanied by Gina Rinehart yet again suggesting we need to be more like Africa.

The great thing about Australian business leaders is they always have something to whinge about, and almost without fail the amount they have to pay their workers will be top of the list.

On Tuesday, the Australian’s front page pictured Rinehart looking across the Indian Ocean with wistful longing. Under the headline High costs hurting mining, she argued that an example of Australia’s poor competitiveness was that “Rio Tinto, which has been in Australia for decades, and made most of its revenue from Australia, is now arranging multibillions of dollars of investment for a major resource project with substantial infrastructure in Guinea in Africa”.

Her positive view of Africa compared with Australia is long held. Back in 2012 she was saying that “Africans want to work, and its workers are willing to work for less than $2 per day. Such statistics make me worry for this country’s future.”

It’s worth noting that she wasn’t worried about what having people work for $2 a day in Australia would do to the social fabric of this country.

It’s also worth noting that Rio Tinto does continue to invest heavily in Australia. It’s 2014 second quarter report noted it has projects in Australia in the earliest stage for aluminium, copper and uranium, at the advanced stage for copper, and at the evaluation stage for copper, aluminium, uranium and iron ore.

But yes, they also have one project for iron ore at the evaluation stage in Guinea. Who knew a multinational mining company would mine in multiple nations!

However, as I reported last week, mining investment consultants Behre Dolbear judge Australia as second only to Canada as the best place for mining investment. Similarly the most recent report by the World Bank on ease of doing business ranked Australia as 11th out of 189 nations. Canada was ranked 19th and Guinea was rather well behind in 175th place.

And we shouldn’t think mining operations in Africa are always profitable endeavours. Yesterday Rio Tinto sold its coal assets in Mozambique for US$50m, having bought them in 2010 for a whopping $4bn. Ouch.

Rinehart’s statements coincided with the release of a discussion paper by the Business Council of Australia, Building Australia’s Competitive Advantage, and an associated McKinsey & Co report titled Improving Australia’s Global Competitiveness.

The McKinsey report suggested that Australia was highly competitive only in agriculture, mining, tourism, finance and international education. The report noted that competitiveness is a product of a nation’s productivity and its cost of doing business.

One way to examine this is to use the “real exchange rate” – that is, the exchange rate taking inflation into account. If a nation’s real exchange rate rises (as Australia’s has in the past five years) then it becomes less competitive.

The question though is why this occurred.

The real exchange rate can rise because the nominal exchange rate is rising, or it can be because inflation and labour costs are rising due to high costs and falling productivity. Since early 2009, when the Australian dollar crashed to a value of just US$0.64, our real exchange rate has risen by about 35%, but in that time the nominal exchange rate has also risen by 33.5%.

So in the past five years the main reason for our declining competitiveness is the nominal exchange rate, not because our labour costs have been rising faster than other nations.

Indeed, since 2005, Australia’s real unit labour costs have fallen by more than in Britain, Canada or the US:

Similarly, any decline in competitiveness since 2005 is not due to a drop in labour productivity since Australia’s productivity growth in that time has beaten Britain, Canada, Japan and the OECD:

Even the Business Council of Australia (BCA) acknowledges this, noting, “labour productivity growth has been relatively robust over the past couple of years”. But it also notes the labour productivity is only part of the story – multi-factor productivity, which combines both labour and capital (business) productivity, has not performed as well:

As I have noted in the past, this is because capital productivity growth in the past decade has been woeful. During the mining boom, mining companies invested in low productive mines purely because the high iron ore and other minerals prices made such mines profitable. That is no longer the case: iron ore and coal prices are half what they were in February 2011:
